maml:description.maml:para: Copy module sample quiz files.
If you decide to create a new location for $PSQuizPath, you can use this command to copy the sample quizzes from the PSQuizMaster module to the new folder. The location must already exist.
Specify the target folder. It is assumed that the location will be your new value for $PSQuizPath. The folder must already exist.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specify the target folder. It is assumed that the location will be your new value for $PSQuizPath. The folder must already exist.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Copy-PSSampleQuiz -Path C:\work\quizzes\
Directory: C:\work\quizzes
Mode LastWriteTime Length Name ---- ------------- ------ ---- -a--- 7/6/2024 11:03 AM 2494 Aliases.quiz.json -a--- 7/7/2024 2:21 PM 6202 demo.quiz.json -a--- 7/7/2024 2:21 PM 4156 remoting.quiz.json

maml:description.maml:para: Get quizzes from the default quiz path.

Use this command to find quiz files. The default is to search for all quiz files in the $PSQuizPath variable, although you can specify a different path. The quiz file must follow the naming convention of <shortname>.quiz.json.
Specify a quiz name.
Enter the path to the folder with quiz json files. The quiz files must follow the naming convention of <shortname>.quiz.json.
Specify a quiz name.
Enter the path to the folder with quiz json files. The quiz files must follow the naming convention of <shortname>.quiz.json.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-PSQuiz
Path: C:\work\quizzes\Aliases.quiz.json [7/7/2023 6:28:58 PM]
Name Version Description Questions ---- ------- ----------- --------- PowerShell Aliases 0.6.0 A short quiz on using aliases .... 3
Path: C:\work\quizzes\demo.quiz.json [6/29/2023 9:15:26 AM]
Name Version Description Questions ---- ------- ----------- --------- My Demo Quiz 0.3.0 This is a demo quiz file 7
Path: C:\work\quizzes\pshelp.quiz.json [7/7/2023 6:29:22 PM]
Name Version Description Questions ---- ------- ----------- --------- PowerShell Help 0.2.1 How to use help 2
Path: C:\work\quizzes\remoting.quiz.json [7/5/2023 11:36:18 AM]
Name Version Description Questions ---- ------- ----------- --------- PowerShell Remoting 0.2.1 A short quiz on PowerShell remoti... . 5

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-PSQuiz -Name "*remoting*" | Format-List
Name : PowerShell Remoting Author : Jeff Hicks Version : 0.2.0 Description : A short quiz on PowerShell remoting concepts. Questions : 5 Updated : 7/5/2023 11:36:18 AM Path : C:\work\quizzes\remoting.quiz.json

dev:remarks.maml:para: You can use wildcards with the quiz name.

maml:description.maml:para: Run a PowerShell quiz
Use this script to test your knowledge of PowerShell commands, which given the Verb-Noun naming pattern should be pretty easy.

The default behavior is to use all cmdlets and functions from installed modules with an option to exclude an array of module names. Wildcards are allowed. You also have the option to specify a single module for testing.
You can specify a single module for testing. The default is all modules.
This is used to indicate a continuing test. You should never need to use this parameter.
Enter a path and filename for a quiz transcript.
Enter a comma separated list of module names to ignore. You can use wildcards.
This is used to indicate a continuing test. You should never need to use this parameter.
Enter a path and filename for a quiz transcript.
You can specify a single module for testing. The default is all modules.
Enter a comma separated list of module names to ignore. You can use wildcards.
This is used to indicate a continuing test. You should never need to use this parameter.
Enter a path and filename for a quiz transcript.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Invoke-PSQuickQuiz
PowerShell Pop Quiz
Given this short cmdlet description:
Creates a new System.Windows.Markup.RoutedEventConverter
What command would you use?
[1] Invoke-CauScan [2] Clear-Tpm [3] Remove-WindowsCapability [4] Get-IscsiTargetServerSetting [5] New-RoutedEventConverter
Select a menu choice [1-5]: 5
You are Correct!!
Do you want another question? Press any key to continue or Q to quit: q You scored 1 correct out of 1 for a GPA of 5. Your grade is A.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Launch the quiz but only use commands from the Hyper-V module.
Launch the quiz using all modules except ISE, WPK and any modules that start with 'my'.
Launch the quiz using all modules except ISE, WPK and any modules that start with 'my'. Record results in a transcript file, C:\Work\quiz.txt.

maml:description.maml:para: Start a PowerShell quiz
Use this command to start a quiz. You can specify the path to the quiz file or use the name of a quiz that is in the $PSQuizPath location.
Enter the full path to the quiz file. The command will auto-complete quiz files found in $PSQuizPath.
Specify the quiz name.
Enter the full path to the quiz file. The command will auto-complete quiz files found in $PSQuizPath.
Specify the quiz name.

maml:alert.maml:para: This command has an alias of Start-PSQuiz.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Invoke-PSQuiz -Path C:\work\quizzes\Aliases.quiz.json PowerShell Aliases [v0.2.0] Question 1/2
What command will display currently defined PowerShell aliases? --------------------------------------------------------------------------- [1] Show-Alias [2] Get-AliasDefinition [3] $PSAlias [4] Get-Alias [5] Find-PSAlias [6] Quit --------------------------------------------------------------------------- Select a menu choice [1-5]:

dev:remarks.maml:para: The command will auto-complete quiz files found in $PSQuizPath.
Get a quiz using a wildcard pattern and pipe it to Invoke-PSQuiz, using its alias Start-PQuiz, to begin the quiz.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new quiz.

This command serves as a kind of "wizard" to guide a quiz creator through the process of creating a quiz file with questions. You can modify the quiz file later by modifying the JSON file or using Set-PSQuizFile.
Use the MaskAnswer parameter if you want to hide the answers in the JSON file.
Specify the folder for the new quiz file. The default is $PSQuizPath.
Mask the answer so it is not displayed in plain text in the JSON file. You can use Unprotect-PSQuizFile to unmask the answers.
Specify the folder for the new quiz file. The default is $PSQuizPath.
Mask the answer so it is not displayed in plain text in the JSON file. You can use Unprotect-PSQuizFile to unmask the answers.

maml:alert.maml:para: This command has an alias of Make-Quiz. If you run this command from within the integrated terminal in VSCode or in the PowerShell ISE, you can use the dynamic parameter, UseEditor, to open the new file in the current editor.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> New-PSQuiz -Path d:\temp What is the full name of your quiz?: Using PowerShell Help What is the short quiz name? This will be used as part of the file name: pshelp Enter a quiz description. You can always edit this later: A brief quiz on using the PowerShell help system Enter the author name: Jeff Hicks Enter the question: What command do you use to install the latest version of the help documentation? Enter the answer: Update-Help Enter a comma-separated list of distractors: Install-Help,Get-Help,Find-Help,Get-Help -online Enter any notes for this question: A few errors are to be expected when running Update-Help Add another question? (Y/N): n
Name : Using PowerShell Help Author : Jeff Hicks Version : 0.1.0 Description : A brief quiz on using the PowerShell help system Questions : 1 Updated : 07/05/2023 12:53:23 Path : D:\temp\pshelp.quiz.json

dev:remarks.maml:para: The default path location is $PSQuizPath. You can specify a different location with the -Path parameter.

maml:description.maml:para: Create an empty quiz file
This command will create an empty quiz file. You can then use New-PSQuizQuestion to define a new set of questions and add them to the file using Set-PSQuizFile.
Enter your quiz name.
Enter your quiz short name which will be used as part of the filename.
Enter the quiz author.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Enter a quiz description
Specify encoding for the text file.
Don't overwrite an existing file with the same name.
Enter the path or directory to store the quiz json file.
Enter a semantic version number for your quiz
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Enter the quiz author.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Enter a quiz description
Specify encoding for the text file.
Enter your quiz name.
Don't overwrite an existing file with the same name.
Enter the path or directory to store the quiz json file.
Enter your quiz short name which will be used as part of the filename.
Enter a semantic version number for your quiz
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

maml:alert.maml:para: If you run this command from within the integrated terminal in VSCode or in the PowerShell ISE, you can use the dynamic parameter, UseEditor, to open the new file in the current editor.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> New-PSQuizFile -Name "PowerShell Scripting" -ShortName scripting -Author "Jeff Hicks" -Description "A quick quiz on PowerShell scripting" -Path d:\temp
Directory: D:\temp
Mode LastWriteTime Length Name ---- ------------- ------ ---- -a--- 07/05/2024 13:03 580 scripting.quiz.json
PS C:\> Get-Content D:\temp\scripting.quiz.json { "metadata": { "name": "PowerShell Scripting", "author": "Jeff Hicks", "description": "A quick quiz on PowerShell scripting", "version": "0.1.0", "id": "f3d3b784-b838-405e-84fb-594600c82189", "updated": "2024-07-05 17:03:45Z" }, "questions": [] }

dev:remarks.maml:para: The default location is $PSQuizPath. You can specify a different location with the -Path parameter.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new quiz question.
Use this command to create a quiz question. You should save it to a variable and then add it to a quiz file with Set-PSQuizFile.
Enter the question text.
Enter the answer. Enclose in single quotes if using a variable or $_. Or escape the $.
Enter an array of distractors. Do NOT include your answer. 3-5 distractors is a good target.
Enter an optional note to be displayed on correct answers. Enclose in single quotes if using a variable or $_. Or escape the $.
Enter the answer. Enclose in single quotes if using a variable or $_. Or escape the $.
Enter an array of distractors. Do NOT include your answer. 3-5 distractors is a good target.
Enter an optional note to be displayed on correct answers. Enclose in single quotes if using a variable or $_. Or escape the $.
Enter the question text.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $q = New-PSQuizQuestion -Question "What is the default script execution policy" -Answer "Restricted" -Distractors "Unrestricted","AllSigned","RemoteSigned","Bypass" -note "Execution policy is not a security setting." PS C:\> Set-PSQuizFile -Path D:\temp\pshelp.quiz.json -Question $q -Version 0.2.0

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create a new question and then add it to a quiz file. The question Note is optional.
Run through the prompts to setup a new quiz question. The output will be converted to JSON and copied to the Windows clipboard. You can paste the question directly into the quizzes JSON file.

maml:description.maml:para: Mask answers and distractors in a PSQuiz file.

PSQuizzes are stored by default in plaintext JSON files. You can use this command to mask the answers and distractors. The obfuscation technique is not complicated and anyone with access to this module can easily reveal the answers. But this will deter casual "cheating."
For best results, your answers should be in text and not a numeric answer. If you must use a numeric answer, it must not be three digits.
Enter the path of the quiz json file.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Enter the path of the quiz json file.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Remove the PSQuizPath settings file.

When you run Set-PSQuizPath the command creates a JSON file under $HOME called .psquizsettings.json. Use this command if you want to delete the file. This will also set the value of $PSQuizPath back to the module default.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Update a quiz file.
Use this command to update a quiz file. You can update the author, version, description, and questions. You can also add new questions to the quiz file.
Enter the path or directory to store the quiz json file.
Enter a new author for your quiz.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Enter a new description for your quiz.
Enter a new name for your quiz.
Enter in a one or more question items.
Enter an optional update value. The default is today.
Enter a new version number for your quiz.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Enter a new author for your quiz.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Enter a new description for your quiz.
Enter a new name for your quiz.
Enter the path or directory to store the quiz json file.
Enter in a one or more question items.
Enter an optional update value. The default is today.
Enter a new version number for your quiz.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Save the user's PSQuizPath setting to a file.

The default location of $PSQuizPath is the module sample quiz folder. This global variable is the default for most commands in this module. Use this command to set a new location. This value will be stored in a settings file under $HOME called .psquizsettings.json. You shouldn't need to do anything with this file. If the file exists, the module will set $PSQuizPath to the saved value.
The $PSQuizPath variable will also be updated to use the new location.
Specify the new value for $PSQuizPath. This will be stored as a persistent value until you change it. The folder must already exist.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Display the new folder location.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Display the new folder location.
Specify the new value for $PSQuizPath. This will be stored as a persistent value until you change it. The folder must already exist.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-PSQuizPath C:\work\quizzes\ PS C:\> $PSQuizPath C:\work\quizzes\

maml:description.maml:para: Unmask answers in a PSQuiz file.
If you masked answers in a PSQuiz file, you can use this command to update the file with unmasked answers and distractors. If the file has not been protected, nothing will be done.
Enter the path of the quiz json file.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
